answers.author: Sandra Slappey
answers.text:
Absolutely!  It's one of the key competencies in my department's leadership and management philosophy and training.  Staff, especially managers, have to be aware of their own emotions and of staff's emotions when dealing with situations.  Ignoring these can result in poor outcomes, even if the specific task issues are addressed.  Both relationships and tasks must be managed to have a high-functioning agency.

answers.author: Rachel Leininger
answers.text:
I couldn't agree more with Sandra!  Emotional intelligence allows a manager to understand how employees are receiving their particular management style/approach, how to motivate employees, as well as being able to treat team members as individuals.  It is important as managers that we understand that we may have to alter our communication and management styles with each employee in order to have them produce the best work possible.  Each employee is an individual and thus responds differently.  Emotional intelligence (including the ability to pick up on non-verbal cues) allows the manager to sense each of his employees reactions to management decisions in a way that produces the highest quality of work.  I believe high emotional intelligence is a key indicator of not only a good manager, but of a good leader.  A manager who cannot understand the feelings and levels of happiness of his/her staff will not only disengage staff members, but will not be able to redirect poor management decisions.

Agreed. I'd just add that the EQ terminology makes it a technical or analytical quality, as though it can be tested and measured. We're still talking about intuition, gut feeling, and habit. The science reading body language or using fMRI to detect emotion is still developing.
Diction matters. Is there a benefit to more old-fashioned language like empathy, compassion, warmth, or civility? We were reading Washington's notes on civility the other day --the 18th warns us against looking down at our phones among company.

Joseph, second string where your negativity is "shining" through.  It will come out when you interview and it will come out in your dealings with other ICMA members.  EQ is important, and it is not about "charisma".  It is about being able to identify the emotional levels (including anger) of you, your staff and your colleagues and to adjust your words and actions accordingly.

answers.author: Patsi Maroney
answers.text:
In our most recent training needs assessment, "interpersonal communication skills" ranked as one of the highest needs.  Emotional Intelligence skills are exactly that;  when you can recognize your own emotions, recognize others' emotions, have empathy for people (especially those who think or believe differently than you), and effectively regulate your own behavior, then you can more easily communicate and manage differences in a productive and solution-oriented way.  We purposefully include EQ skill-building in our leadership development programs in order to help grow people's so-called 'soft skills'.

answers.author: Joseph Ohler
answers.text:
We seem to have a quandary: people are saying, "Yes, we need to understand emotional intelligence, BUT we cannot measure it." So in one person's opinion, someone has high emotional intelligence, whereas another will perceive that person as a jerk. How do you reconcile differing opinions of a candidate's emotional intelligence other than saying, "I don't like him, and you shouldn't either?"
That would seem to open the door to tons of discrimination -- the key is whether the discrimination is based on a protected status. A candidate may have to prove that an "incompatible" personality is due to a documented, medically recognized disability AND that s/he can do the job with proper accommodation of that personality. Most organizations won't accommodate, however, and will write off the candidate as a "poor organizational fit" -- the catch-all death knell for otherwise qualified applicants.
